member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnscopedRefAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate a byref escapes and is not scoped.

remarks.para: There are several cases where the C# compiler treats a as implicitly - where the compiler does not allow the to escape the method.

For example:
for instance methods.
parameters that refer to types.
parameters.
This attribute is used in those instances where the should be allowed to escape.

Applying this attribute, in any form, has impact on consumers of the applicable API. It is necessary for API authors to understand the lifetime implications of applying this attribute and how it may impact their users.

member.summary: Calculate the offset from the start using the giving collection length.
member.param: The length of the collection that the Index will be used with. length has to be a positive value

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.ModuleInitializerAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate to the compiler that a method should be called in its containing module's initializer.
member.remarks:
When one or more valid methods with this attribute are found in a compilation, the compiler will emit a module initializer which calls each of the attributed methods.
Certain requirements are imposed on any method targeted with this attribute: - The method must be `static`. - The method must be an ordinary member method, as opposed to a property accessor, constructor, local function, etc. - The method must be parameterless. - The method must return `void`. - The method must not be generic or be contained in a generic type. - The method's effective accessibility must be `internal` or `public`.
The specification for module initializers in the .NET runtime can be found here: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/design/specs/Ecma-335-Augments.md#module-initializer

member.name: T:BizHawk.Client.Common.IInputApi
member.summary: for querying host input

member.name: M:BizHawk.Client.Common.IInputApi.Get
member.returns:
Map of key/button names (of host) to their pressed state.
Only pressed buttons will appear (with a value of ), unpressed buttons are omitted.
member.remarks:
Includes gamepad axes (!axis.isNeutral, with sticks as 4 "buttons" suffixed "Up"/"Down"/"Left"/"Right").
Includes mouse buttons, but not axes (cursor position and wheel rotation). Unlike , these have the names "WMouse L", "WMouse R", "WMouse C", "WMouse 1", and "WMouse 2" for LMB, RMB, MMB, Mouse4, and Mouse5, respectively.
See for keyboard key names, though some are overridden by (check the source).

member.name: M:BizHawk.Client.Common.IInputApi.GetMouse
member.returns: Map of (host) mouse button/axis names to their state: either for a button (button.isPressed), or for an axis.
member.remarks: Buttons are "Left", "Right", "Middle", "XButton1", and "XButton2" for LMB, RMB, MMB, Mouse4, and Mouse5, respectively. Mouse position is axes "X" and "Y". Mouse wheel rotation is the "Wheel" axis.

member.name: M:BizHawk.Client.Common.IInputApi.GetPressedAxes
member.returns:
Map of (host) axis names to their state.
Axes may not appear if they have never been seen with a value other than 0 (for example, if the gamepad has been set down on a table since launch, or if it was recently reconnected).
member.remarks: Includes mouse cursor position axes, but not mouse wheel rotation. Unlike , these have the names "WMouse X" and "WMouse Y".

member.name: M:BizHawk.Client.Common.IInputApi.GetPressedButtons
member.returns: List of (host) key/button names which are pressed (i.e. were pressed when EmuHawk last polled; this is distinct from virtual gamepad polling/latching). Unpressed buttons are omitted.
member.remarks:
Includes gamepad axes (!axis.isNeutral, with sticks as 4 "buttons" suffixed "Up"/"Down"/"Left"/"Right").
Includes mouse buttons, but not axes (cursor position and wheel rotation). Unlike , these have the names "WMouse L", "WMouse R", "WMouse C", "WMouse 1", and "WMouse 2" for LMB, RMB, MMB, Mouse4, and Mouse5, respectively.
See for keyboard key names, though some are overridden by (check the source).

member.name: P:BizHawk.Client.Common.Config.SoundVolume
member.value:
volume level; interpreted as a percentage (i.e. scaled down to 0.0..1.0) and passed to the platform audio implementation, which should use it as a simple multiplier on each sample;
so 0 is scale each sample by 0x (mute),100 is scale each sample by 1x (preserve full volume), 50 is scale each sample by 0.5x ( -3 dB), and 25 is scale each sample by 0.25x ( -6 dB)

member.name: P:BizHawk.Client.Common.Config.SoundVolumeRWFF
member.value: when rewinding or fast-forwarding, the sample amplitude multiplier is multiplied by this value (after conversion from percentage), or in other words, remains in effect

member.remarks: This is separate from because its large size slows or prevents design-time code analysis.

member.name: F:BizHawk.Client.Common.PolarRectConversionData._r2x
member.remarks: generated with ruby: def f(r, ) (r * Math.cos( * Math::PI / 180)).round end; puts (0..181).map {|r| "{" + (0..359).map {|| f(r, )} * ", " + "}"} * ",\n"

member.name: F:BizHawk.Client.Common.PolarRectConversionData._r2y
member.remarks: generated with ruby: def f(r, ) (r * Math.sin( * Math::PI / 180)).round end; puts (0..181).map {|r| "{" + (0..359).map {|| f(r, )} * ", " + "}"} * ",\n"

member.name: F:BizHawk.Client.Common.PolarRectConversionData._xy2r
member.remarks: generated with ruby: def f(x, y) Math.hypot(x < 128 ? x : x - 256, y < 128 ? y : y - 256).round end; puts (0..255).map {|x| "{" + (0..255).map {|y| f(x, y)} * ", " + "}"} * ",\n"

member.name: F:BizHawk.Client.Common.PolarRectConversionData._xy2
member.remarks: generated with ruby: def f(x, y) x1 = x < 128 ? x : x - 256; (180 * (y < 128 ? Math.atan2(y, x1) / Math::PI : Math.atan2(y - 256, x1) / Math::PI + 2)).round end; puts (0..255).map {|x| "{ " + (0..255).map {|y| f(x, y)} * ", " + " }"} * ",\n"

Buffer size mask, used to wrap values in the ringbuffer correctly
